issues.title: Gap Analysis: Modelling of Optical Pluggables in Packet Over Optical Network
issues.author: dieterbeller
issues.body:
This gap analysis is trying to collect YANG models from various sources (primarily from IETF, OpenConfig, etc.) for modeling optical pluggables located in client devices like IP routers, which are connected to an optical WDM transport network. This material will be analyzed in order to identify potential gaps.

References:
- https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang
- https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/ietf-ccamp-layer0-types-ext-RFC9093-bis
- https://github.com/openconfig/public
- etc.

issues.title: Review of I-D 00 version
issues.author: sergiobelotti
issues.body: This issues has to collect possible comments/suggestions on the first version (00) of I-D proposed .

comments.author: sergiobelotti
comments.body:
Some comments:
-_Normative reference_
Add Optical Impairments draft “A YANG Data Model for Optical Impairment-aware Topology”  [draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang-14 - A YANG Data Model for Optical Impairment-aware Topology](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang/14/)
Add Interface model draft “A YANG model to manage the optical interface parameters for an external transponder in a WDM network” [draft-ietf-ccamp-dwdm-if-param-yang-10 - A YANG model to manage the optical interface parameters for an external transponder in a WDM network](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ccamp-dwdm-if-param-yang/)
-_Abstract_
I would change the sentence” Drawing from existing models in IETF, OpenConfig, ITU-T, OIF, and TAPI, this model offers enhanced uniform structuring and naming.” Into
“Drawing from existing IETF models, maybe be complementing that with input from other standard or industrial forum models (ITU-T, OpenConfig , ONF TAPI  etc.) , this model offers enhanced uniform structuring and naming.”
About the attributes as said we start with IETF attributes from Optical Impairment and then we need to understand if those are enough or not, and then we can dig into other models to see if e.g. OpenConfig is proposing something needed for us.

 “Additionally, it provides insight into the mapping to plug interface structures defined in CMIS.” 

About CMIS and the need to expose internal protocol between host and pluggable I’m personally not clear the need for that. 
Considering the CMIS interface as a device-internal interface  I think that a very limited amount of information needs to be exposed to the controller defined in a YANG module. 
The purpose of the YANG model should be to ensure that the transceiver optical pluggable is configured
properly from an optical WDM network perspective (TX/RX frequency setting/power setting/operational mode setting, etc).

_-Introduction_
I think we need to clarify and then converge, on what is the real purpose of this model. As I said in my view what we need to model is the necessary configuration parameters that are important from an optical transport network perspective. This seems map on the first bullet you have in the introduction:
“Optical media interface: This defines the characteristics of the optical solution such as spectrum, polarization, and dispersion, which do not directly affect the behavior of the host packet device.”
So this bullet means that our model should provide the correct parameters needed for an optical PNC to calculate suitable optical circuit and spectrum allocation.

I do not understand how the second and third bullet that you mention is affecting the needed attributes to be configured in the prospective of an optical feasibility computation. 
The second bullet seems to me more an internal set of characteristics that should be clarified why would be need to expose.
The third bullet seems related to specific physical characteristics of the pluggable , we would need to go into details here to understand if needed to be exposed in the model.

comments.author: dieterbeller
comments.body:
General comments:

- It looks like comments cannot be easily added to the I-D [draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md](https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/blob/main/draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md) in markdown format (maybe I just don't know how to do it).
- I created the txt file based on [draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md](https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/blob/main/draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.md) and pasted it into this comment below.
- The txt file should always be put on GitHub next to the markdown file and should be kept in sync with the markdown file.

```
Common Control and Measurement Plane                            R. Rokui
Internet-Draft                                                     Ciena
Intended status: Informational                                    A. Guo
Expires: 27 August 2024                           Futurewei Technologies
                                                               P. Bedard
                                                                   Cisco
                                                          B. Swamynathan
                                                                   Nokia
                                                              G. Grammel
                                                                 Juniper
                                                        24 February 2024


     Modelling of Optical Pluggables in Packet Over Optical Network
         draft-poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling-latest

Abstract

   This draft outlines the modeling of optical pluggables within a host
   packet device within the context of a packet over optical network.
   The model encompasses all pertinent properties of the pluggable for
   various packet over optical use cases and is partitioned into three
   primary areas: the optical media interface, the electrical plug to
   host interconnect, and the physical equipment of the pluggable.

   Included in the model are representations of configuration, states,
   and telemetry data, as well as profiles and coherent plug
   capabilities.  Emphasizing the importance of considering both vendor-
   agnostic and vendor-specific attributes in modeling coherent
   pluggables.

   Drawing from existing models in IETF, OpenConfig, ITU-T, OIF, and
   TAPI, this model offers enhanced uniform structuring and naming.
   Additionally, it provides insight into the mapping to plug interface
   structures defined in CMIS.

About This Document

   This note is to be removed before publishing as an RFC.

   The latest revision of this draft can be found at
   https://italobusi.github.io/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/draft-poidt-
   ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.html.  Status information for this
   document may be found at https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-
   poidt-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling/.






Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 1]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   Discussion of this document takes place on the Common Control and
   Measurement Plane Working Group mailing list (mailto:ccamp@ietf.org),
   which is archived at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/ccamp/.
   Subscribe at https://www.ietf.org/mailman/listinfo/ccamp/.

   Source for this draft and an issue tracker can be found at
   https://github.com/italobusi/actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling.

Status of This Memo

   This Internet-Draft is submitted in full conformance with the
   provisions of BCP 78 and BCP 79.

   Internet-Drafts are working documents of the Internet Engineering
   Task Force (IETF).  Note that other groups may also distribute
   working documents as Internet-Drafts.  The list of current Internet-
   Drafts is at https://datatracker.ietf.org/drafts/current/.

   Internet-Drafts are draft documents valid for a maximum of six months
   and may be updated, replaced, or obsoleted by other documents at any
   time.  It is inappropriate to use Internet-Drafts as reference
   material or to cite them other than as "work in progress."

   This Internet-Draft will expire on 27 August 2024.

Copyright Notice

   Copyright (c) 2024 IETF Trust and the persons identified as the
   document authors.  All rights reserved.

   This document is subject to BCP 78 and the IETF Trust's Legal
   Provisions Relating to IETF Documents (https://trustee.ietf.org/
   license-info) in effect on the date of publication of this document.
   Please review these documents carefully, as they describe your rights
   and restrictions with respect to this document.  Code Components
   extracted from this document must include Revised BSD License text as
   described in Section 4.e of the Trust Legal Provisions and are
   provided without warranty as described in the Revised BSD License.

Table of Contents

   1.  Terminology . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   3
   2.  Introduction  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   3
   3.  Packet over optical converged network context . . . . . . . .   5
   4.  Optical Pluggable Building Blocks . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   6
   5.  Optical Pluggables Data Modeling  . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
   6.  Optical Pluggables Yang Model . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
   7.  Security Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7



Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 2]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   8.  IANA Considerations . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
   9.  References  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
     9.1.  Normative References  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   7
     9.2.  Informative References  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8
   Acknowledgments . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8
   Contributors  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8
   Authors' Addresses  . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .   8

1.  Terminology

   The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT",
   "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and
   "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in
   BCP 14 [RFC2119] [RFC8174] when, and only when, they appear in all
   capitals, as shown here.

   The following terms abbreviations are used in this document:

   *  Optical Plug / Coherent Pluggables / Pluggable: A small form
      factor coherent optical module

   *  O-PNC: The control functions specializing in management/control of
      optical and photonic functions (virtual or physical).  See
      [RFC8453]

   *  P-PNC: The control functions specializing in management/control of
      packet functions (virtual or physical).  See [RFC8453]

   *  CMIS: Content Management Interoperability Services developed by
      OIF is an open standard that allows different content management
      systems to inter-operate over the Internet

   *  xPonder: Short for Transponder and/or Muxponder

2.  Introduction

   Packet traffic has been transmitted across optical networks for many
   years, leveraging the advantages of optical transmission and
   switching combined with packet switching.  Traditionally, optical
   systems and packet systems have been distinct, each with their own
   dedicated devices.

   In numerous network setups, packet and optical networks have been
   engineered, operated, and managed separately, leading to siloed
   operations that can be suboptimal and inefficient.  The evolution of
   both packet and optical systems has largely been independent.
   Optical systems, in particular, have seen advancements in capacity,
   especially with the adoption of coherent optical techniques.



Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 3]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   Advancements in optical component design have led to increased
   density, enabling entire coherent optical terminal systems that
   previously required multiple circuit packs to now fit into a single
   small form factor "coherent pluggable."  Integrating coherent
   pluggables into devices with packet functions can result in reduced
   network costs, power consumption, and footprint, while also enhancing
   data transfer rates, reducing latency, and expanding capacity,
   although in some cases, separate packet and optical solutions may
   still be preferred due to other engineering and deployment
   considerations.

   These trends, coupled with the desire to utilize the best components
   available, have given rise to open optical pluggables.  These
   pluggables allow a plug from one vendor to be installed in a device
   from another vendor with packet functions.  Communication between
   coherent pluggables and the packet device host occurs through the
   CMIS standard developed by OIF [OIF-CMIS].

   While standardized transmission modes like ZR can handle basic
   applications, proprietary modes from vendors are often necessary to
   achieve optimal performance.

   This draft outlines the modeling of an optical pluggable within a
   host packet device within the context of a packet over optical
   network.  The model presented in this document consolidates various
   properties of optical pluggables into three key areas:

   *  Optical media interface: This defines the characteristics of the
      optical solution such as spectrum, polarization, and dispersion,
      which do not directly affect the behavior of the host packet
      device.

   *  Electrical plug-to-host interconnect: This defines the
      characteristics of the bus interconnect between the host and the
      plug, such as lane count and FEC, which both the optical pluggable
      and the packet host must understand and act upon.

   *  Physical and functional aspects of the pluggable: This defines
      attributes of the optical pluggable itself, such as plug type,
      version, thermal characteristics, and power consumption, which
      indirectly affect the packet host.










Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 4]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


   The coherent pluggable model provides representations for
   capabilities, profiles, configurations, and states and telemetry
   data.  Capabilities are defined in profiles related to operational
   modes, with some capabilities potentially being proprietary
   Configurations include attributes for optical settings, monitoring
   capabilities, and test capabilities, while state and telemetry data
   include dynamic properties such as performance monitoring collections
   and alarm notifications.

   Both vendor-agnostic and vendor-specific attributes are important
   considerations in the modeling of coherent pluggables.

   The document is divided into the following sections:

   *  Section 3: Packet over optical converged network context

   *  Section 4: Coherent Pluggables Building Blocks

   *  Section 5: Coherent Pluggables Data Modeling

   *  Section 6: Coherent Pluggables Yang Model

3.  Packet over optical converged network context




























Rokui, et al.            Expires 27 August 2024                 [Page 5]
 
Internet-Draft        Modelling Optical Pluggables         February 2024


                  |---------------|
                  |   P-PNC(s),   |
                  |   O-PNC(s),   |
                  |   MDSC        |
                  |---------------|
                          ^
                          |  (A)
      +-------------------|-------------------+
      |                   |                   |  Packet Device
      |                   V                   |  Vendor X
      |        |---------------------|        |  (i.e, Host)
      |        |                     |        |
      |        v                     v        |
      |  |-----------|          |----------|  |
      |  | Packet    |          | Coherent |  |
      |  | Function  |..........| Plug     |  |
      |  | Data      |          | Data     |  |
      |  |-----------|          |----------|  |
      |        .                      .       |
      |        .                      . (B)   |
      |        .                      .       |
      |  |--------------|   (C)   |------------------|  (D)

      +---------------------------------------+

  Legend

           Figure 1: Packet device with optical pluggables
```

comments.author: dieterbeller
comments.body:
Afaik, an OIF Implementation Agreement (IA) cannot be a normative reference in an IETF RFC:

```
9.1.  Normative References

   [OIF-CMIS] OIF Forum, "OIF Implementation Agreement (IA) Common
              Management Interface Specification (CMIS))", OIF CMIS IA ,
              April 2022, <https://www.oiforum.com/wp-content/uploads/
              OIF-CMIS-05.2.pdf>.
```
It can only be an informative reference!

I concur with the comment from @sergiobelotti above that the CMIS interface is a device-internal interface and the configuration parameters for pluggables, which shall be exposed to controllers via a potential YANG model (those relevant for the optical WDM transport network), must be selected carefully. This is at least my understanding of the scope of this draft.

issues.title: Clean up Terminology
issues.author: ggrammel
issues.body:
Unify terminology across the text:
- If the context is about pluggability and/or physical form factor, call it -> pluggable module
- if the context is about optics, call it ->  optical module
- If the context is strictly about coherent, call it -> coherent optical module

The draft is about gap analysis for pluggable vs. non-pluggable and gaps in optical modeling.

The CMIS {{CMIS}} defines the most common communication interface between host devices and optical modules. Other kind of interfaces may be developed and standardized in the future.

Hi All,

```suggestion
In certain cases, a coherent pluggable may support attributes that are specific to a particular vendor of the pluggable module which may be different from the vendor of the  Packet Device.

This draft refers to such attributes as "Opaque Attributes". Given that coherent pluggables encompass capability, configuration, and performance monitoring (PM)/state attributes, each category may contain opaque attributes. Consequently, the opaque attributes could include the following:
```

In this context it would be better to qualify the vendor as pluggable vendor or packet device vendor:

```suggestion
As an example, let's assume a pluggable vendor defines secret attribute "DD" for its coherent pluggable. Vendor first needs to augment IETF data model with a list of encrypted values and memory-maps shown in {{solution-4}}. This very similar to {{solution-1}} where essentially the host functions as a proxy, transmitting the values from the NBI to the appropriate memory-map locations on the pluggable without needing to understand the meaning and semantics of these attributes.
```

```suggestion
           draft-rokui-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling-03
```

```suggestion
docname: draft-rokui-ccamp-actn-wdm-pluggable-modelling-latest
```

This Implementation Agreement (IA) defines the Common Management Interface
Note that CMIS targets any pluggable modules, not only Coherent ones

Abstract: Specification (CMIS), which may be used by pluggable or on-board modules, such as
QSFP Double Density (QSFP-DD), OSFP, COBO, QSFP, as well as by existing or future
module developments with host to module management communication based on a
two-wire interface. This IA is targeted for systems manufacturers, system integrators,
and suppliers of CMIS compliant modules.

Why is this for coherent only? I would have thought that a Repository could be applicable for any kind of pluggable, rather than limiting it to coherent. IOW there is a gap between focus on coherent work and pluggable work related to non-coherent stuff.

we should be clear about what we are discussing in this draft:
- not all pluggables are coherent
- not all coherent pluggables are DWDM
- not all DWDM interfaces are pluggable
-

I can't find O-PNC and P-PNC being defined in RFC845. Besides, the term "The control functions specializing in management/control of optical and photonic functions (virtual or physical)." is quite nebulous. E.g.:
- is interface up/down a photonic function because the laser is switched off?
- are uncorrected errors packet or optical "specialities"?
- is a transponder with a non coherent interface on client side and a coherent one on the media side supposed to be managed/controlled by the P-PNC?

The goal of this draft is to identify gaps pertinent to pluggables. It should not be the goal to define YANG data models that are rlated to the media side and independent from the fact that there is a pluggable module or a fixed implementation.

as there is no guaranteed 1:1 mapping between Media Logical Channels and Host Logical Channels, the figure should contain a mapping-block function in between.
Depending on the L0/L1 modeling discussion, we may need to structure this accordingly (FFS)
we did not define what we'd count as "functional capabilities" in general. I would assume these are related to pluggables in general and not limited to the media side only.
ITU-T defined the application code which is a particular branch. It is confusing (but not wrong) to add it to the list of organizational modes. Suggest to remove it from the list of examples.

Supported modes are per media interface and not specific to pluggable optical modules. The following description is intended to provide the context along coherent interfaces. YANG Modeling work is being performed in: https://github.com/ietf-ccamp-wg/draft-ietf-ccamp-optical-impairment-topology-yang and https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-ccamp-dwdm-if-param-yang/) for further details.

Isn't this draft about he gap analysis? I would suggest to split the current text into two drafts:
- gap analysis: Identifies gaps related to existing work in IETF
- pluggable modeling: adding YANG models to to cover pluggable specifics referring to the gaps identified earlier

We should draw clearer distinction between gap analysis vs. modeling proposals. If there is a gap identified related to TCA, it has to be clear which is the reference for the gap. 
if there is a proposed solution for the gap it is better to discuss this in a separate draft.
see earlier comment. All of above is reasonable, but where are the gaps and what has to be done to close them? we should be clearer on the scope of this work.

found this in RFC3224 and suggest to copy it to describe a VOE: 
   This specification introduces only one new protocol element, the
   Vendor Opaque Extension.  This Extension makes it possible for a
   vendor to extend SLP independently, once the vendor has registered
   itself with IANA and obtained an Enterprise Number.  This is useful
   for vendor-specific applications.
what is the specific thing here related to pluggables? vendor opaque attributes are not bound to pluggable form factors. Furthermore, what is the gap identified here compared to e.g. SNIA/OIF ids?

I don't get this rationale. it is up to the host implementation to decide which attributes to recognize and support. Even non-opaque attributes may not be supported on all platforms and for good reasons.

Is there any precedent for such far-reaching decisions in IETF? If vendors want to add vendor specific extensions, they are at liberty to do so. It is not the job of a standard to define how to do it. Probably a good idea to ask the OPS-WG about feedback and suggestions.

This is about reading/writing memory maps, which is exactly what CMIS wants to improve because it is not scalable and hard to understand and debug. I would not suggest to see a YANG model for register map programming.

As discussed earlier, we better split the draft into a gap analysis and YANG proposal. The gap (opaque attributes) have not been defined and agreed as a gap compared to current IETF work. Coming up with YANG work that is detached from existing work isn't helpful and should not be mixed in tha same draft as the gaps.
it may look simple but is impossible to debug. We should leave register maps to other SDOs
This is not what a standard is supposed to cover. Vendors are free to implement their proprietary extensions.memory-map programming is not what a standard should facilitate.
I would really be interested in the feedback of the OPS-WG on such things. My take is that such things should be kept outside of standards.YANG modules are not supposed to program register maps.
see earlier comments

which vendors want to conceal and why are they confidential and to whom and for what purpose? I'd expect from a gap analysis a much clearer identification of the gap and why it needs to be defined in a standard.
Encryption? I would be very curious how the Security AD would view this.
If a vendor has a secret attribute, let him decide how to augment the model instead of poking a security hole into the system.

reviews.author: ggrammel
reviews.body:
The current text looks is mixing three aspects together and should be split into 3 drafts:
1. Lifecycle Management: this could be a framework document to provide the necessary definitions and context for the subsequent work.
2. Gap analysis of programmable optical pluggables: This shall identify the unique properties of pluggables and identify gaps with respect the baseline drafts (basically topology and dwdm-if) which already cover the media-side.
3. YANG-model extensions: this shall reference the gaps identified and suggest YANG augmentations to current work.

Another aspect is to suggest opaque provisioning, which is a dangerous thing to do because it is a security hole and cannot be debugged. Such proposals need to be well motivated and ought to be cleared by the Security-AD and OPS-WG before pursuing them.

---------------
This draft outlines the optical pluggable attributes within a host packet device, focusing on their role in a packet-over-optical network. It includes representations of coherent pluggable capabilities, configuration, states, and telemetry data. These attributes draws from existing IETF standards and incorporates input from other industry forums and standards, such as ITU-T, OpenConfig, OIF and ONF TAPI, to ensure uniform structuring and consistent naming conventions. Note that the IETF terminology shall be given precedence wherever possible. In case there is a duplication of an attribute, this draft may describe how the attribute is named in the related document. Only if no attribute exists in IETF RFCs or IETF WG drafts, new attributes shall be introduced if they are needed.

A gap analysis is included to compare optical pluggable attributes with current IETF drafts, identifying any modeling gaps. Based on the identified gaps, the draft proposes solutions to address missing attributes, such as augmenting or updating existing IETF YANG models.

The lifecycle of an optical pluggable, from operator approval and viability assessment to deployment and monitoring, is also addressed.

[Editor's note: This may be covered in a separate document, currently under investigation.] Additionally, this draft introduces the concept of a "Coherent Pluggable Repository", which maintains a repository of pluggable capabilities. It also includes a gap analysis of coherent pluggable attributes in existing IETF drafts and other SDOs, providing a comprehensive view of the lifecycle of a coherent pluggable, from operator approval through to deployment

reviews.body:
Reviewed up to line 772 "Appendix A"

1) we generally need to be specific with terminology. I.e. the optical description is not dependent whether a module is pluggable or not. I suggested a terminology definition.
2) a gap analysis is supposed to identify gaps between what there is (i.e. existing IETF work) and some other reference (i.e. OIF). FOr optical parameters, it is clear that the gap is in between IETF-topology/ietf-DWDM-if and other standards (as identified in our google doc). In much of the rest it is unclear between which documents the gap appears to exist. i.e. is there a gap between remote inventory drafts and what is desired for pluggable modules?
3) The text delves into specific controller architectures, but the scope of the draft is about (pluggable) modules themselves. It would be better to keep these aspects in different drafts.

comments.body:
Suggest to focus on the gap analysis aspect and shorten the intro to:

This draft provides a gap analysis with respect to existing IETF work in the following areas:
1) it provides an analysis of optical attributes provided by other organizations and identifying modeling gaps in current IETF drafts. 
2) it identifies modeling needs addressing the specific aspect of pluggability of transceiver modules. The authors recognize the fact that that not all pluggable modules are coherent, not all coherent pluggable modules are DWDM capable and not all DWDM capable interfaces are implemented as pluggable modules. This analysis identifies gaps to manage the lifecycle of an optical pluggable module, from operator approval and viability assessment, to deployment, monitoring and phase-out.

> [Editor's note: Solutions for the pluggable aspect may be covered in a separate document, currently under investigation.] 
> [Editor's note: The lifecycle of pluggable modules may be covered in a separate document, currently under investigation.]

A gap analysis should not introduce new things but rather identify gaps. A new draft should describe how those gaps van be addressed.

original md-text:

CMIS: The Common Management Interface Specification is an OIF Implementation Agreement (IA) which provides a well-defined mechanism to initialize and manage optical (and copper) modules in a standard way, while still providing the capability to provide custom functionality. This commonality makes integration into different host platforms easier for both the host and module vendors. This Implementation Agreement (IA) defines the Common Management Interface. Specification (CMIS), which may be used by pluggable module or on-board modules, such as QSFP Double Density (QSFP-DD), OSFP, COBO, QSFP, as well as by existing or future module developments with host to module management communication based on a two-wire interface. This IA is targeted for systems manufacturers, system integrators, and suppliers of CMIS compliant modules {{CMIS}}.

proposed update:

Common Management Interface Specification (CMIS): The Common Management Interface Specification is an Implementation Agreement (IA) developed by the Optical Internet Forum (OIF) {{CMIS}}. This specification defines an interface for managing optical (and copper) modules in a standardized way while still permitting vendor-specific functionality. It eases the integration of modules supporting the CMIS interface into host platforms from different system vendors. It shall be noted that CMIS targets any module, not only coherent optical modules, which is the scope of this document. The CMIS interface is applicable to on-board module types (fixed optics) as well as pluggable modules types such as QSFP Double-Density (QSFP-DD), OSFP, COBO, QSFP and other module types.
